title: 105_s2106
content: The "Arches National Park Expansion Act of 1998" is cited as the short title. It amends the boundary expansion of Arches National Park in Utah as per Public Law 92-155. The Arches National Park Expansion Act of 1998 establishes the park boundaries to include the Lost Spring Canyon Addition, totaling approximately 3,140 acres. Additionally, it amends the acquisition of property as per Public Law 92-155. The Secretary will transfer jurisdiction over the Lost Spring Canyon Addition from the Bureau of Land Management to the National Park Service. Additionally, livestock grazing regulations under Public Law 92-155 are amended. The Lost Spring Canyon Addition will be transferred to the National Park Service, and grazing leases, permits, and licenses will be continued for the lifetime of the holder and their direct descendants before being permanently retired. The holder of a grazing lease, permit, or license is entitled to periodic renewal until the expiration of the specified period. The sale of such lease, permit, or license can only occur if the purchaser permanently retires it upon acquisition. This provision does not affect other provisions related to leases, permits, or licenses under the Taylor Grazing Act. The National Park Service will administer any grazing lease, permit, or license for land in the Lost Spring Canyon Addition. Additionally, Section 5 of Public Law 92-155 is amended to ensure the protection and development of the park in accordance with laws applicable to the National Park System. Federal land in the Lost Spring Canyon Addition is withdrawn from public land laws, including mineral leasing laws. The inclusion of the area in the park does not impact the operation of the natural gas pipeline by Northwest Pipeline Corporation. Congress acknowledges that a parcel of State school trust land is partially within the Lost Spring Canyon Addition. The Lost Spring Canyon Addition in Arches National Park is being exchanged for Federal land outside the area to allow for Federal management. This exchange is in the interest of both the State of Utah and the United States. The Lost Spring Canyon Addition in Arches National Park is being exchanged for Federal land outside the area to allow for Federal management, in the interest of both the State of Utah and the United States. SEC. 8. LAND EXCHANGE INVOLVING SCHOOL TRUST LAND. The State of Utah can transfer school trust land to the United States, and in return, the United States will transfer Federal land to Utah. The exchange must be completed within 1 year of enactment, with simultaneous conveyances of title. The land exchange under this section is subject to valid existing rights, with each party succeeding to the rights and obligations of the other party regarding any encumbrances on the exchanged land. The State of Utah will convey school trust land, while the Secretary will convey Federal land of approximately 639 acres. The Federal land is considered to be of equivalent value to the school trust land. The State of Utah must consult with the Utah State Office of the Bureau of Land Management before any surface disturbing activities on acquired land. They must also manage archaeological, paleontological, and cultural resources on the acquired lands in accordance with Federal law. The State is required to preserve existing grazing and other land uses as much as possible. State school trust land must preserve existing grazing, recreational, and wildlife uses on acquired lands. Utah can authorize activities allowed by land management plans. Implementation of the land exchange must be completed within 180 days of enactment.
